RelatedSentence: But if N.C. lawmakers approve the $ 49 million cut to higher education Gov. Pat McCrory has proposed for 2014-2015 , the state could sink to the bottom in terms of funding to our university system , too .

Already , the Tar Heel state is among an ignominious group of eight states where politicians last year slashed funding to higher education while all the other states boosted spending on their public colleges and universities .

Already , the Tar Heel state is among an ignominious group of eight states where politicians last year slashed funding to higher education while all the other states boosted spending on their public colleges and universities .

Already , the Tar Heel state is among an ignominious group of eight states where politicians last year slashed funding to higher education while all the other states boosted spending on their public colleges and universities .

A1: most other Southern states , including Mississippi , Georgia and Tennessee
RelatedSentence: Neighboring South Carolina was among those increasing higher ed funding - as did most other Southern states , including Mississippi , Georgia and Tennessee .
Worse , the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities said this month , North Carolina was among a handful of states last year that cut higher education the most .
Worse , the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities said this month , North Carolina was among a handful of states last year that cut higher education the most .
But once again , North Carolina finds itself in a leading position where it is preferable to be trailing .
In 2011 , the UNC system had to cut $ 80 million , or 3.4 percent , of its overall budget .
Since 2008 at UNC Chapel Hill , budget reductions have meant eliminating 493 positions , cutting 16,000 course seats and increasing class sizes .
Since 2008 at UNC Chapel Hill , budget reductions have meant eliminating 493 positions , cutting 16,000 course seats and increasing class sizes .
Critics have dubbed McCrory 's proposal the rob - Peter - to - pay - Paul budget .
That 's because the higher education cuts would help pay for much - deserved raises for the state 's public school teachers .
The stagnant pay has put North Carolina 46th in teacher pay nationally .
But they should find the money to do so from somewhere else .
These higher education cuts are hurting the university system 's ability to educate the skilled and diverse workforce North Carolina needs to grow and thrive .
